metadata.title: Title: Two-Dimensional Planar Supercapacitor Based on Zinc Oxide/Manganese Oxide Core/Shell Nano-architecture Authors: C.Justin

sections.text:
Accepted Manuscript
Title: Two-Dimensional Planar Supercapacitor Based on Zinc Oxide/Manganese Oxide Core/Shell Nano-architecture Authors: C.Justin Raj, Murugesan Rajesh, Ramu Manikandan, Ju Yong Sim, Kook Hyun Yu, Sang Yeup Park, Jun Ho Song, Byung Chul Kim PII: S0013-4686(17)31427-5 DOI: http://dx.doi.org/doi:10.1016/j.electacta.2017.07.009 Reference: EA 29826 To appear in: Electrochimica Acta Received date: 25-5-2017 Revised date: 26-6-2017 Accepted date: 2-7-2017 Please cite this article as: C.Justin Raj, Murugesan Rajesh, Ramu Manikandan, Ju Yong Sim,KookHyunYu, SangYeupPark, JunHoSong,ByungChulKim,Two-Dimensional Planar Supercapacitor Based on Zinc Oxide/Manganese Oxide Core/Shell Nanoarchitecture, Electrochimica Actahttp://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.electacta.2017.07.009 This is a PDF file of an unedited manuscript that has been accepted for publication. As a service to our customers we are providing this early version of the manuscript. The manuscript will undergo copyediting, typesetting, and review of the resulting proof before it is published in its final form. Please note that during the production process errors may be discovered which could affect the content, and all legal disclaimers that apply to the journal pertain.

sections.heading: Two-Dimensional Planar Supercapacitor Based on Zinc Oxide/Manganese
C. Justin Raja, Murugesan Rajesha, Ramu Manikandana, Ju Yong Sima, Kook Hyun Yua,
sections.text:
Sang Yeup Parkc, Jun Ho Songd, Byung Chul Kima,b*
a Department of Chemistry, Dongguk University-Seoul, Jung-gu, Seoul-04620, Republic Korea. bARC Centre of Excellence for Electromaterials Science, IPRI, AIIM Facility, Innovation Campus, University of Wollongong, NSW 2522, Australia. c Department of Ceramic Engineering, Gangneung-Wonju National University, Gangneung25457, Republic of Korea. d Technology Innovation Center for Fine Ceramic, Gangneung-Wonju National University Gangneung, 25440, Republic of Korea. * Corresponding author, E-mail: bkim1961@dongguk.edu (B.C. Kim); Tel.: +82 2 2260 3709, Fax.:+82 2 2208 8204
Graphical abstract
Highlights
 Planar supercapacitor was fabricated on FTO substrate using ZnO/MnO2 core/shell 3
D structure
 α-MnO2 form of shell layer was deposited over ZnO NRs using simple SILAR
technique
 The shell layer was optimized by coating various SILAR cycles of MnO2 layers  Planar supercapacitor shows excellent areal capacitance and electrochemical
performances
Abstract
We report the fabrication and performance of zinc oxide core/manganese oxide shell (ZnO/MnO2) three-dimensional nanostructured planar supercapacitor. In this particular fabrication, ZnO nanorods were grown over FTO substrate followed by the successive ionic layer adsorption and reaction (SILAR) deposition of MnO2 nanostructure on ZnO nanorods. The quality of the ZnO/MnO2 electrode was optimized by performing various cycles of SILAR deposition of MnO2 layer over ZnO core. The electrode with 7 cycles of MnO2 deposited demonstrated maximum electrochemical performance with area capacitance of 14 mF cm-2 and the same condition was utilized for the fabrication of a symmetric planar supercapacitor. This ZnO/MnO2 3D architecture planar supercapacitor showed maximum area capacitance of 5 mF cm-2 in 1 M Na2SO4 aqueous electrolyte with good energy density of 4.07 × 10 -7 Wh cm-2 and power density of 3.19 mW cm-2. Moreover, this planar supercapacitor shows an excellent electrochemical performance with comparable long term cyclic stability.
Keywords: Planar supercapacitor; zinc oxide; impedance spectroscopy; core/shell structure; metal oxide
1. Introduction
In recent years, worldwide attention has been focused on emerging wearable and miniaturized electronics, so there is an increasing demand for smart and efficient energystorage devices to fulfil the energy requirement of the macro- to micro-components in electronics[1, 2]. The commercial energy storage systems such as batteries and supercapacitors are not applicable for miniaturized electronics due to their significant weight and bulkiness. Interestingly, electrochemical supercapacitors have been demonstrated to deliver high power density and unlimited cycle life at fast charge/discharge processes with the possibility to design any type of feasible architecture like, light weight, flexible, micro type, in-planar etc[3, 4]. Especially, the devices such as microelectromechanical systems (MEMS), miniaturized biomedical devices, sensors, integrated on-chip components and printed electronics can significantly benefit from planar thin film supercapacitors for energy storage and power generations[5, 6]. The in-plane pattern of supercapacitor takes advantage of the thin layered, flat morphology and it is ideal for 2D devices. Also, this design could offer the entire device to be much thinner, lighter and compatible. Moreover, in a planar design the usage of a spacer can be eliminated due to the 2D transport of electrolytic ions between the electrodes. Concerning the 2D transport of ions, the supercapacitor can be termed as 2D planar supercapacitor[7-9]. Recently, numerous work has been reported on supercapacitors based on planar configuration utilizing, graphene oxide[6], graphene[10], carbon nanotubes[11], onion like carbon[12], conducting polymer polypyrrole[9] etc., with different forms and architecture.
The metal oxide nanostructures are an interesting class of materials for the fabrication of supercapacitor electrodes owing to their pseudocapacitance nature, robustness and high theoretical specific capacitance value. The existence of pseudocapacitance property in metal oxides is mainly due to its fast and reversible Faradaic reactions (redox reactions) during the
charge and discharge processes tending to show high energy density that is even comparable with batteries. Metal oxide nanostructures such as RuO2, MnO2, Co3O4, NiO, V2O5 etc., [13- 16] have been studied intensively and applied for supercapacitor electrodes. From these, MnO2 is interesting and the most studied pseudocapacitance material due to its low cost, low toxicity, high theoretical capacitance (1370 F g-1), and excellent capacitive performance in aqueous electrolytes [17-19]. However, poor electronic conductivity and limited surface area of MnO2 limited its specific capacitance values that are still far below the theoretical value. In order to achieve high capacitive performance, a large surface area and a fast ion/electron transport by the electrode material are important. Therefore, various alterations had been made on MnO2 nanostructure by forming composites with various conducting carbon or polymer materials, doping with conducting metal ions and forming core/shell design with other electrochemically active materials. [20-25] Among them, the core/shell architecture is an interesting aspect where it is possible to construct hierarchical core/shell structures with other electroactive materials to improve the surface area of active material, enhance electrolyte ions and electron transport rates, and use the electrochemical properties of the core/shell material to obtain high specific capacitance values.[26, 27]
Recently, various hybrid designs of nanostructures such as Co3O4/MnO2, Zn2SnO4/MnO2,
SnO2/MnO2, ZnO/MnO2 etc., have been demonstrated as efficient supercapacitor electrodes[15, 27-29]. In particular, 1D nanowire/nanorod arrays have attracted considerable attention for the construction of core/shell structures due to the synergy of the materials, easy transport of electrons through a linear path, usage of whole active material by the electrolyte ions etc. For example, the ZnO/MnO2 core/shell structure, since ZnO is an attractive functional semiconductor material, has a feeble capacity and can be easily processed into required lengths of 1D nanowires or nanorods structures.[30, 31] Thus, these ZnO nanorods can effectively be used as a core material for any electroactive shell materials, and moreover can act as an efficient
mechanical support and electron conducting pathway to develop core/shell nanostructure structures because of its comparable mechanical stability, conductivity and high chemical stability in neutral electrolyte.[32, 33]
In this present work, a 2D planar supercapacitor was designed over fluorine doped tin oxide (FTO) substrate using MnO2 embedded ZnO nanorod as the core/shell configuration. The ZnO nanorod was grown by a low temperature hydrothermal method and the MnO2 nanostructure was decorated by conventional SILAR deposition technique over the free standing ZnO nanorods. The SILAR deposition was optimized by studying the electrochemical properties of various cycles coated ZnO/MnO2 electrodes performed in a three-electrode setup. The best optimized electrode (7 cycles with maximum specific capacitance 14 mF cm-2) was utilized for the fabrication of a planar supercapacitor. The electrochemical supercapacitor performance of the device was characterized using cyclic voltammetry (CV), galvanostatic charge/discharge tests and electrochemical impedance spectroscopic analysis. This ZnO/MnO2 planar supercapacitor showed a maximum areal capacitance of 5 mF cm-2 in 1 M Na2SO4 aqueous electrolyte with excellent electrochemical performance. Apart from the operation of the planar supercapacitor, the detailed structural, morphological properties of the electrode and electrochemical properties the ZnO/MnO2 half-cell have been studied and are discussed.
2. Experimental Methods
2.1 Fabrication of ZnO/MnO2 core/shell electrode
The vertically aligned array of Zinc oxide nanorods (ZnO NR) were grown on fluorine doped tin oxide (FTO) substrate through conventional seeded low temperature hydrothermal growth technique. Initially, ZnO seed layer was coated over a clean FTO substrate (1×1 cm2) by spin coating using a precursor of 0.25 M zinc nitrate hexahydrate (Zn(NO3). 6H2O) in absolute ethanol solution. The spin coating was repeated over three time and was heat treated at 300 °C
for 30 min in an oven to acquire a homogeneous ZnO seed layer. The ZnO NR were grown by placing the seeded substrate facing downward in a pyrex bottle containing aqueous solution of 0.05 M Zn(NO3)2 and 0.05 M hexamethylenetetramine at 95 °C for 6 h in a hot air oven. Finally, the ZnO NR array substrate was rinsed with DI water, dried and heat treated at 400 °C for 30 min in order to attain better crystallinity. The MnO2 shell was formed over the resultant ZnO NR core by conventional SILAR deposition technique. The as-grown ZnO NR substrate was immersed in an aqueous solution consisting of 0.01 M Manganese(II)sulfate pentahydrate (MnSO4. 5H2O) for 1 min, to allow Mn ions to adsorb over the ZnO NR, and rinsed with DI water to remove the excess un-adsorbed Mn ions and dried in preheated hot plate at 120 °C for 1 min. Then the dried substrate was dipped into aqueous solution containing 0.05 M potassium permanganate (KMnO4) for 1 min, where the pre-adsorbed Mn was oxidized with KMnO4 and formed as MnO2 nanoparticle over ZnO NR. Then the electrode was rinsed with DI water, ethanol and dried on a hot plate. The formation of the MnO2 shell over ZnO NR core was clearly visible through the change of white color ZnO film to dark brown color. These twoconsecutive dipping procedures are termed as one cycle, and for optimizing the MnO2 shell condition, the various SILAR cycles were performed such as 3, 5, 7 and 9 cycles. Finally, a layer of silver paste was coated at the top of the electrode to ensure better ohmic contact. The photographic images of the fabricated bare ZnO NR and ZnO/MnO2 electrodes are shown in Fig. 1S a) and b).
2.2 Fabrication of ZnO/MnO2 core/shell 2D planar supercapacitor
The ZnO/MnO2 core/shell based planar supercapacitor (SC) was also fabricated on FTO substrate. The schematic representation of the ZnO/MnO2 planar supercapacitor is diagrammatically depicted in Fig. 1. Initially, an appropriate area of FTO substrate was coated with ZnO seed layer as mentioned above. The seed layer coated FTO was masked with vacuum tape forming two parallel electrodes and leaving ~1.5 mm gap between adjacent electrodes.
Then the gap was filled with zinc powder and 1M hydrochloric acid was dropped over the area to etch the unprotected FTO surface. After etching for 1 min the electrode was rinsed in DI water and the mask was removed, then subjected for the growth of ZnO NR. Similarly, a MnO2 shell layer was also coated over the ZnO NR for 7 cycles and the etched portion was cleaned again using a sharp needle to remove SILAR deposited MnO2 particles in this area. Finally, tops of the two parallel electrodes were coated with conducting silver paste to ensure better ohmic contact. The photographic and optical microscopic image of the ZnO/MnO2 planar SC are shown in Fig. 1S c) and 2S respectively.
2.3 Characterization The structure of the synthesized ZnO/MnO2 thin film was identified using a powder X-ray diffractometer (XRD, Rigaku, Ultima IV) with Ni filtered Cu Kα radiation (λ=1.5418Å) operated at 40 kV and 30 mA in the 2θ range 5°- 80°. Morphologies and elemental analysis (EDAX) of ZnO and ZnO/MnO2 thin films were observed by scanning electron microscopy (SEM) (JEOL-7500FA field emission SEM (Japan)) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM) (JEOL (Japan) model JEM-2100F). Electrochemical measurements such as cyclic voltammetry, galvanostatic charge/discharge test and impedance spectroscopy were performed at room temperature (20 °C) using a ZIVE-SP2 (Korea) electrochemical workstation. For 3- electrode measurements, half-cell arrangement included the working electrode of ZnO/MnO2 thin film, a platinum counter electrode and a Ag/AgCl reference electrode in 1M Na2SO4 aqueous electrolyte. Similarly, the electrochemical performance of the planar SC was measured in 1M Na2SO4 aqueous electrolyte.
3. Results and Discussion
The X-ray diffraction pattern of the fabricated ZnO/MnO2 (7 cycle SILAR) thin film
is shown in Fig. 2a. The resultant XRD pattern of the ZnO NR array shows the hexagonal wurtzite phase of crystallization with single dominated (002) peak, indicating an upstanding ZnO NR array growing along the c-axis (JCPDS No. 36-1451). No characteristic peaks of MnO2 were observed due to the formation of very thin shell layer over highly crystalline ZnO NR core. But on very close examination, the XRD pattern shows a broad, noisy and low intensity peak between 26° to 29° (shown in magnified portion) representing the diffraction due to (310) plane of tetragonal α-MnO2 crystal phase (JCPDS No.44-0141)[34]. This low intensity broad peak reveals the existence of very small nanoparticles of MnO2 embedded over the ZnO NR.
Furthermore, the formation of MnO2 shell over the ZnO core was confirmed through EDAX spectral analysis. Fig. 2b shows the resultant EDAX spectrum of ZnO/MnO2 thin film, which clearly shows the presence of Mn elemental counts along with the Zn and O respectively.
Fig. 3(a) and (b) show the different magnification SEM images of bare ZnO thin film,
displaying vertically well aligned nanorods with hexagonal morphology of ~200 nm diameter. The low and high magnification SEM images of MnO2 coated ZnO NR thin film are shown in Fig. 3 (c) and (d). From the figure, it is clear that the MnO2 nanoparticles are perfectly embedded over the ZnO NR forming as a core/shell morphology. The MnO2 shows nearly spherical morphology with a size < 50 nm and highly accumulated over the tip of each ZnO NRs resembling a flower like morphology. The magnified SEM image shows the MnO2 particles not only coated on the top of NRs, but also decorated the entire surface of the ZnO NRs.
Further, the morphology of ZnO/MnO2 thin film was observed through TEM and HRTEM analysis. Fig. 4 (a) and (b) show the corresponding TEM and HRTEM images of the sample.
From the image, the MnO2 shell formation over ZnO NR is clearly detected. The HRTEM image shows the accumulation of the MnO2 nanoparticles over the ZnO NR surface resembling decoration of quantum dots over ZnO nanorods [35].
Electrochemical capacitance behavior of the ZnO/MnO2 electrode was measured by
cyclic voltammetry (CV) in a three-electrode and planar full-cell configuration. The measurements were carried out within the potential window of 0 to 0.8 V at various scan rates using 1M Na2SO4 electrolyte. Fig. 5a shows the cyclic voltammograms of ZnO/MnO2 electrode with 3, 5 and 7 cycles SILAR coated MnO2 shells. The CV curves show that the background of the curve increases with respect to the coating cycles of MnO2 shell layer. To assess the influence of MnO2, the CV curves of bare ZnO electrode are presented in Fig. S3, which clearly show noisy voltammograms with extremely small background current representing a poor supercapacitor behavior. Thus, even a small layer of MnO2 over ZnO can effectively change the charge storage capability of the electrode due to the pseudocapacitive nature of the material. From the overall coating cycles, 7 cycles MnO2 coated electrode shows high background current and nearly a rectangular shape curve than lower cycle coated electrodes.
The areal capacitance (Careal) value was calculated from CV data according to Equation (1)
Careal = ∫ idV /2(A × s × ∆V) (1) where, A is the total area of active material on electrodes (cm2), s is the scan rate (mV s-1), i is the voltammetric current (A), and ΔV is the potential window of the CV curve. The electrodes show a maximum areal capacitance value of 11.43 mF cm-2 for 7 cycles MnO2 coated electrode and show maximum areal capacitances of 2.97 and 6.23 mFcm-2 respectively for 3 and 5 cycles coated electrodes at 5 mV s-1 scan rate. Moreover, the coating cycle was extended up to 9 cycles, when the electrode shows even slightly higher areal capacitance value (12.06 mFcm-2) at low scan rate than 7 cycles MnO2 coated electrode. But at high scan rate the areal capacitance
value dropped lower than that of 7 cycles MnO2 coated electrode (9 cycles 1.8 mFcm -2 and 7 cycles 3.3 mFcm-2 at 100 mVs-1 scan rate). Since, excess coating of MnO2 can form more aggregates and which can control effective transportation of electrolytic ions to the interior of the electrode at high scan rate. So, the 7 cycles MnO2 shell layer coated ZnO NR is believed to be the optimized SILAR cycles and used for the whole experiment. The CV curves of 3, 5 and 7 cycles coated ZnO/MnO2 electrodes at various scan rates are presented in Fig. S4 (a), (b) and (c) respectively. Fig. 5b shows the CV curves of 7 SILAR cycles coated ZnO/MnO2 planar supercapacitor at various scan rates from 5 to 300 mV s-1. The curves show nearly rectangular shape for all the measured scan rates, representing the good capacitance behavior of the ZnO/MnO2 planar supercapacitor. The planar device shows a maximum areal capacitance value of 3.64 mF cm-2 at 5 mV s-1 scan rate. Moreover, the device displays a rectangular profile of CV curve even at high scan rate (300 mV s-1) with a reasonable areal capacitance value of 1.03 mF cm-2 indicating higher power capacity of the device. The variation of areal capacitance values with respect to scan rate for the 3, 5 and 7 cycles coated MnO2 based ZnO/MnO2 electrodes are shown in Fig. 5c. From the plot, it is clear that the 7 cycles shell coated ZnO NR electrode shows higher areal capacitance for all the measured scan rates than other lower cycles coated electrodes and all the electrodes display same trends of decrease in capacitance values with respect to increase in scan rate. The inset of Fig. 5c depicts the variation of area capacitance values of the planar supercapacitor for different scan rates and similar trends of capacitance decay are observed with respect to increase in scan rates. Because, at slow scan rate the electrolyte ions have sufficient time to interact with the whole active surface of the electrode and exhibits high capacitance value, but at high scan rates, the ions transfer is limited within the outer surface of electrode and which subsequently reduces the capacitance value.[36]
A more reliable assessment of the capacitance performance of the half-cell electrodes
and planar SC was performed by utilizing galvanostatic charge/discharge test (GCD) using various charge/discharge current densities over the potential window of 0-0.8 V. The charge/discharge profiles of ZnO/MnO2 at a constant charge/discharge current density of 0.1 mA cm-2 are shown in Fig. 6a. The corresponding charge/discharge curves for various charge/discharge current densities of individual electrodes are displayed in Fig. S5a-5c. The GCD curves of ZnO/MnO2 planar SC at various charge/discharge current densities ranging from 0.025 to 5 mA cm-2 are shown in Fig. 6b. The GCD curves for 3, 5, 7 cycles electrodes and planar SC display nearly symmetrical curves with slightly tilted triangular shape revealing that the capacitance originates from the pseudocapacitance nature of the electrode[37, 38]. Similar to the CV analysis, the 7-cycles coated electrode displayed enlarged CGD curve with prolonged discharging time showing higher capacitance behavior than the other two low cycles coated electrodes. Moreover, the GCD profile of ZnO/MnO2 planar SC shows slightly good symmetrical charge/discharge curve than the 3-electrode cells, representing betterment of this core/shell configuration for the construction of planar SCs.
Areal capacitance (Careal) values from galvanostatic charge/discharge experiments
were calculated according to Equation (2)
𝐶𝑎𝑟𝑒𝑎𝑙 = 𝐼 × ∆𝑡/𝐴 × ∆𝑉 (2) where I is the applied current (A), A is the total active area of the electrodes (cm2), ∆t
is the discharge time (s) and ∆V is the potential window (V).
Fig. 6 (c) and (d) show the variation of calculated areal capacitance with respect to the
applied discharge current densities. The cells show good and comparable areal capacitance in half-cell configuration, 0.2 - 2.05 mF cm-2 for 3-cycles electrode, 0.387 - 5.42 mF cm-2 for 5- cycles electrode, and 1 - 14 mF cm-2 for 7-cycles electrode for discharge current densities ranging from 10 to 0.1 mA cm-2. Similarly, the planar SC shows excellent areal capacitance of 0.53 - 5 mF cm-2 for discharge current densities ranging from 5 to 0.025 mA cm-2 in 1M Na2SO4
electrolyte. The obtained areal capacitance of ZnO/MnO2 planar SC is comparable or higher than the values reported for planar thin film SCs[7, 11, 39-41]. The list of areal capacitance values of the previously reported planar SCs are presented in Table S1.
Further the electrochemical performance of the planar SC was evaluated by Ragone plot based on areal capacitances obtained from galvanostatic charge/discharge curves. The energy density and the power density of the SC were estimated according to:
𝐸 = 1/2 × 𝐶𝑎𝑟𝑒𝑎𝑙𝑉 2 (3) and 𝑃 = (E/∆𝑡) × 3,600 (4) where E is the energy density (Wh cm-2), V is the operating potential (V), Careal is the areal capacitance (mF cm-2) of the SCs, P is the power density (W cm-2) and ∆t is the discharge time (s). Inset of Fig. 6d shows the corresponding Ragone plot of ZnO/MnO2 planar SC. The fabricated planar SC shows a comparable energy and power density, i.e., energy density increases from 4.69×10-8 to 4.068×10-7 W h cm-2 when the power density decreases from 3.19×10-3 to 1.595×10-5 W cm-2 respectively.
Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) analysis was performed for the
electrodes and planar SC to study the internal resistance, charge transfer and electrochemical kinetics of the electrodes. The EIS spectra of the electrodes were measured in the frequency range between 0.01 Hz - 100 kHz at 0 V bias potential in 1M Na2SO4 electrolyte. The Nyquist plot for the three electrodes and the planar SC are shown in Fig. 7 (a) and (b), and the plots were analyzed using ZView software on the basis of the electrical equivalent circuits shown in the inset of figures[42-44], which provide a considerable insight of the different capacitive contribution and charge transfer process of the electrodes [45]. The Nyquist plots are composed of a spike in the low frequency region representing the capacitive part, and the high frequency
region consists of an incomplete semicircle indicating intrinsic resistance of the device[46]. In the plot of the half-cell, one can easily observe that the 3 cycles MnO2 coated electrode shows nearly resistive nature even in the low frequency region spike and it tends to rise towards imaginary axis representing the increase in capacitance property with more coating cycles.
The fitted equivalent circuit consists of ohmic resistance Rs representing the
combination of the ionic resistance of the electrolyte, intrinsic resistance of current collector and material/substrate interface resistance[46-48]. The parallel connection Rsl and Csl represents the charge transfer in the surface layer of the electrode materials[42]. The diffusion transport in the semi-infinite geometry can be denote by introducing the Warburg impedance (W1)[43] .The faradaic charge transfer resistance across the electrode/electrolyte interface is denoted as Rct and a double layer capacitance (Cdl) is connected parallel with Rct. For the extreme low frequency spike, the serial connection of Warburg impedance (W2) and capacitance (Cp) were included, which corresponds the diffusion of electrolytic ions and the intercalation pseudocapacitance[49]. The resultant fitted parameters of the EIS plots are presented in Table 1 and the error associated with the fitted data are presented in Table S2, the low percentage of error (≤ 5%) clearly reveals the model was well fitted with the experimental values. From the data, the ohmic resistance is found to be higher than the solution resistance of the electrolyte, since it includes the resistance of the current collector (FTO substrate) and the resistance arises between substrate/electrode materials interface[50]. The Rct value shows a decrease with respect to increase in coating cycles of MnO2, representing the improvement of pseudocapacitance associated with the electrode[46, 51]. This was clearly evidenced through the increase of intercalation pseudocapacitance (Cp) values with respect to the deposition cycles of MnO2 layer on ZnO. In addition, Fig. 7 (c) and (d) show the Bode plots of electrodes and planar SC, which reveal the dependency of modulus of impedance and phase angle on frequency. From the plot, the impedance of the electrode decreases with respect to increase in
MnO2 layer on ZnO and shows low impedance value for 7 cycles coated electrode. In phase plots, the region with the phase angle between 90° and 45° is dominated by capacitive behavior of the electrode, while that between 45° and 0° represented mainly the diffusion and the resistive behavior of the electrode [52]. The 3, 5 and 7 cycles coated electrodes show a maximum phase angle of -39°, -45° and -54° at low frequency region (1 mHz) representing the enhancement of capacitive behavior with respect to the increase in SILAR cycles. But, the phase angle of planar SC approaches towards -90° with a value of -63° showing the improved capacitance nature of the planar SC. However, the phase angles are comparatively lower than that of an ideal capacitor (-90°). This low value of phase angles is mainly due to the pesudocapacitive nature and indicates the semi-infinite linear diffusion occur in the electrode/electrolyte interfaces[53, 54].
The cyclic stability of 7 cycles coated electrode and planar ZnO/MnO2 SCs were
investigated by continuous charge/discharge measurements over 5000 cycles (Fig. 8a) at a constant current density of 5 mA cm-2. The 7 cycles coated ZnO/MnO2 electrode half-cell showed excellent cycling stability with 93% retention of initial areal capacitance value after 5000 cycles. But the ZnO/MnO2 planar SC showed lower and comparable cyclic stability with 74% of areal capacitance retention after 5000 cycles. To verify the capacitance degradation, the SC was subjected to EIS analysis after 5000 cycles of GCD test. Fig. 8b shows the comparative Nyquist plots of planar SC before and after cyclic stability test, the resultant fitted parameters are listed in Table S3. The plot shows a large increase in the Rct value (326.2 Ω cm 2) of the device than the device before 5000 charge/discharge cycles. This increase in Rct value is attributed to the decline in the stability of the ZnO/MnO2 planar SC after 5000 cycles GCD[55].
4. Conclusion
In summary, a planar 2D supercapacitor was fabricated using ZnO/MnO2 3D core/shell structure on FTO glass substrate by simple SILAR deposition of MnO2 shell over ZnO nanorods. The SILAR deposition of shell layer was optimized by performing various deposition cycles. The devices exhibited good electrochemical performance, with areal capacitance of 14 mF cm-2 for 7 cycles in 1 M Na2SO4 electrolyte and 5 mF cm -2 in planar configuration, with an excellent energy density and power density. This investigation of ZnO/MnO2 architecture shows great potential application in energy management for planar and printable electronics. Moreover, the fabrication of planar ZnO/MnO2 design over FTO glass substrate may greatly contribute the effective utilization of this architecture for any patterned surfaces in-planar or micro-supercapacitors.
Supporting Information The additional Figures, tables and references relevant to the manuscript are available in Supporting Information.

sections.heading: Figure Captions
sections.text:
Fig. 1 The schematic representation of ZnO/MnO2 planar supercapacitor. Fig. 2 (a) X-ray diffraction pattern of ZnO/MnO2 thin film, inset shows the magnified portion of the spectrum; (b) EDAX spectrum of ZnO/MnO2 thin film. Fig. 3 Low and high magnification SEM images of (a) and (b) vertically aligned bare ZnO NR; (b) and (c) ZnO/MnO2 core/shell electrode. Fig. 4 (a) TEM and (b) HRTEM of ZnO/MnO2 thin film. Fig. 5 Cyclic Voltammograms for ZnO/MnO2; (a) half-cell of 3, 5, 7 cycle coated MnO2 shell, (b) planar full-cell; and (c) variation of areal capacitance with various scan rates for the halfcells and planar full-cell. Fig. 6 Charge/discharge curves for ZnO/MnO2; (a) half-cell of 3, 5, 7 cycle coated MnO2 shell, (b) planar full-cell; (c) variation of areal capacitance with various discharge current densities for the half-cells and (d) variation of areal capacitance with various discharge current densities for planar full-cell (insert shows the Ragone plot of planar supercapacitor). Fig. 7 Nyquist plots of the (a) half-cells (inset shows the equivalent circuit of fit), (b) planar supercapacitor (inset shows the magnified portion of high frequency region and the equivalent circuit of fit); Bode plots of (c) half-cells and (b) planar supercapacitor. Fig. 8 (a) Cycling stability of the ZnO/MnO2 for 7 cycles half-cell and planar supercapacitor; (b) Nyquist plots of planar supercapacitor before and after cyclic stability test.
Fig. 3 Low and high magnification SEM images of (a) and (b) vertically aligned bare ZnO NR; (c) and (d) ZnO/MnO2 core/shell electrode.
Fig. 4 (a) TEM and (b) HRTEM of ZnO/MnO2 thin film.
Fig. 6 Charge/discharge curves for ZnO/MnO2; (a) half-cell of 3, 5, 7 cycles coated MnO2 shell, (b) planar full-cell; (c) variation of areal capacitance with various discharge current densities for the half-cells and (d) variation of areal capacitance with various discharge current densities for planar full-cell (insert shows the Ragone plot for planar supercapacitor).
Fig. 7 Nyquist plots of the: (a) half-cells (inset shows the equivalent circuit of fit), (b) planar
supercapacitor (inset shows the magnified portion of high frequency region and the equivalent circuit of fit); Bode plots of (c) half-cells and (b) planar supercapacitor.

referenceMentions.context: In recent years, worldwide attention has been focused on emerging wearable and miniaturized electronics, so there is an increasing demand for smart and efficient energystorage devices to fulfil the energy requirement of the macro- to micro-components in electronics[1, 2].

In recent years, worldwide attention has been focused on emerging wearable and miniaturized electronics, so there is an increasing demand for smart and efficient energystorage devices to fulfil the energy requirement of the macro- to micro-components in electronics[1, 2].

Interestingly, electrochemical supercapacitors have been demonstrated to deliver high power density and unlimited cycle life at fast charge/discharge processes with the possibility to design any type of feasible architecture like, light weight, flexible, micro type, in-planar etc[3, 4].
